contentrichtext.text: {{For|the mountain range in [[Montana]]|Bridger Mountains (Montana)}} {{refimprove|date=November 2009}} [[Image:Wpdms nasa topo bridger mountains wyoming.jpg|335px|right|thumbnail|The Bridger Mountains in Wyoming]] The '''Bridger Mountains''' are a short subrange of the [[Rocky Mountains]], approximately {{convert|40|mi|km}} long, in central [[Wyoming]] in the [[United States]].<ref>{{cite peakbagger |rid=14424 |name=Bridger Mountains}}</ref> The range forms a bridge between the [[Owl Creek Mountains]] to the west and the southern end of the [[Bighorn Mountains]] to the east. The [[Wind River (Wyoming)|Wind River]] passes through the gap between the range and the Owl Creek Mountains. [[Bridger Creek]] passes through the gap between the range and the Bighorns. The highest point in the range is Copper Mountain at {{convert|8300|ft|m}}. The range is named after [[Jim Bridger]], who pioneered the [[Bridger Trail]] through the mountains from southern Wyoming into the [[Bighorn Basin]] in 1864. ==See also== * [[List of mountain ranges in Wyoming]] == Notes== {{Reflist}} {{coord|43|30|N|107|51|W|display=title}} [[Category:Mountain ranges of Wyoming]] [[Category:Geography of Hot Springs County, Wyoming]] {{Wyoming-geo-stub}}
